bibl.title: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Philip Showalter Hench, February 8, 1942

div1.p: Kean thanks Hench for returning a letter from Truby. He clarifies the affiliation of Reed and other physicians involved in the yellow fever experiments as to Hospital Corps and Medical Corps, having noted an error in an earlier publication by Wyeth.

div1.head: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Philip Showalter Hench, February 8, 1942
div1.opener:
Walter Reed Gen. Hospital
Ward 8, Room 11.
Sunday Feb 8/42
2804 N STREET, N. W.
WASHINGTON, D. C.
My dear Dr. Hench
div1.p:
I think Mrs. Kean has written
to tell you of my illness, a sudden &,
for a few days, severe one which caused
my return to this Hospital. The infection
of the Kidneys promptly cleaned up
under Sulfothiazole - but then it took
a few days to recover from the effects
of the drug, which are very upsetting
to me. I duly received your note of the
3rd inclosing your Cuban Correspondence
& returning Gen. Truby's letter to me.
The advs of Wyeth by separate envelope
were also duly received. For all of
these evidences of your friendly consid-
eration I am very appreciative.
You seem to have won over the Cubans
completely. The Wyeth adv. is also very

soothing to their national amour propre
with all the Cuban names To the front,
and its tactfulness is admirable.
It distresses me a little as an Army
man to see Major Walter Reed spoken
of as belonging to the ArmyAmerican Hospital
Corps. It should have been the Army
Medical Corps. The Hospital Corps
is the enlisted part of the Army Medi-
cal Department, the Medical Corps being
the Commissioned part. We have also
a commissioned Dental Corps and
Veterinary Corps. But to those outside
of the Army these distinctions are
small matters. Reed's assistants Carroll
Agramonte and Lazear being temporary
(contrat)officers did not belong to either
the Medical Corps or the Hospital Corps
altho they were a part of the Medical
Department. Does all of this seem
very complicated?
